Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Student Travel Support Program for the 2015 V.M. Goldschmidt Conference in Prague, Czech Republic, August 16-21, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support participation by doctoral students in the 2015V.M. Goldschmidt Conference in Prague, Czech Republic, during August 16-21, 2015. This travel grant will enable the best and brightest students from the US and US Territories, students who might otherwise be unable to attend due to financial constraints at their home institutions, to benefit from all the advantages this meeting has to offer at this turning point in their respective careers. The Goldschmidt conference is the premier venue for geochemistry and the chosen students will be exposed to the latest advances in the field of geochemistry. The conference offers an excellent opportunity for networking of students who are close to graduation and will be entering the workforce. In addition to oral and poster presentation in 25 theme sessions, students can participate in field trips and workshops associated with the conference.

Applications will be collected from the students, then reviewed and ranked by a volunteer committee of scientists. The Geochemical Society is contributing $10,000 so that a total of 24 students, who are presenting their work at the conference, will receive $1,250 each toward travel expenses. Considerations for the award are the preparation of the application package, the demonstrated need for the funds, the selection of a diverse pool of applicants based on gender, sex, representation and geographical distribution. Every effort is made to encourage underrepresented minorities and people with disabilities to apply for funding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This National Science Foundation award was used to subsidize travel and conference costs for 16 outstanding young scientists pursuing degrees in geochemistry at 11 different U.S. colleges and universities. Specifically, the award helped them attend and present their scientific work at the 2015 Goldschmidt Conference in Prague, Czech Republic, held August 16-21, 2015. The Goldschmidt Conference is the premier international venue for the dissemination of cutting-edge geochemistry research in a wide range of disciplines, ranging from planetary geology to energy resources to environmental geology. The 2015 conference included 3,719 total participants, of whom 1,190 were students, representing institutions from around the globe. More than 60 applications for NSF-sponsored student travel funds were received from eligible students. A 7-member review committee, comprised of scientists from internationally ranked institutions, evaluated these applications. Each student receiving an NSF award presented a talk or poster at the Goldschmidt Conference, and had the unique opportunity to meet with and learn from an outstanding, international group of scientists. Student feedback indicated that the experience was excellent, with many students reporting significant opportunities to learn, network and establish new collaboration with colleagues from around the world. This professional development opportunity also served to encourage students to continue their STEM education and career paths.
